context:
Program Name: Mechanical Techniques
Code: T149
Credential: Ontario College Certificate
Method of Study: Full-time
Duration: 14 weeks (2 semesters)
Starting Months: May
Domestic Tuition: $3,909.00 *
Centre: Construction & Engineering Technologies
School: Mechanical Engineering Technologies
Location: Casa Loma Campus
Program Description: A 14-week certificate program designed to complement university engineering students' theoretical knowledge with applied practical techniques, covering topics such as manufacturing protocol, engineering drawing, solid modelling (Solidworks), precision machining, quality control, CNC machining with Mastercam, pneumatics/electro-pneumatic circuits, and microprocessor control systems.
Coursework: Emphasizes practical techniques through applied learning and hands-on lab activities. Includes topics on industrial safety, dimensional inspection, machining practices, metal forming, quality control, pneumatics/electro-pneumatic circuits, embedded electronics, Computer-Aided Design (CAD), Computer-Aided Manufacturing (CAM), and Computer Numerical Control (CNC) machining techniques.
Duration: 14 weeks (2 semesters)

question: , What is the focus of the coursework in this program?

context:
Program Name: Mechanical Techniques
Code: T149
Credential: Ontario College Certificate
Method of Study: Full-time
Duration: 14 weeks (2 semesters)
Starting Months: May
Domestic Tuition: $3,909.00 *
Centre: Construction & Engineering Technologies
School: Mechanical Engineering Technologies
Location: Casa Loma Campus
Program Description: A 14-week certificate program designed to complement university engineering students' theoretical knowledge with applied practical techniques, covering topics such as manufacturing protocol, engineering drawing, solid modelling (Solidworks), precision machining, quality control, CNC machining with Mastercam, pneumatics/electro-pneumatic circuits, and microprocessor control systems.
Coursework: Emphasizes practical techniques through applied learning and hands-on lab activities. Includes topics on industrial safety, dimensional inspection, machining practices, metal forming, quality control, pneumatics/electro-pneumatic circuits, embedded electronics, Computer-Aided Design (CAD), Computer-Aided Manufacturing (CAM), and Computer Numerical Control (CNC) machining techniques.
Duration: 14 weeks (2 semesters)

Program: The program is a fast-track certificate program for university engineering students to gain practical engineering concepts.

Courses: The required courses for the program are spread over two semesters. Semester 1 includes Machining Fundamentals (MENG 1048), Mechanical CAD with SolidWorks (MENG 1049), Computer Numeric Control & 2D Computer-Aided Manufacturing (MENG 1058), and Intermediate Machining (MENG 1059). Semester 2 includes Computer Numeric Control & 2D Computer-Aided Manufacturing (MENG 1058), Electronic and Pneumatic Systems (MENG 1060), Quality Assurance (MENG 2052), and no course title is provided for the last code.

Program Learning Outcomes: The graduate of this program will be able to comply with legislation, standards, regulations, and guidelines; contribute to quality control and assurance procedures; comply with current health and safety legislation and organizational practices; support sustainability best practices; use current and emerging technologies; troubleshoot mechanical problems using mathematics and mechanics fundamentals; interpret and prepare mechanical drawings; perform routine technical measurements; and assist in manufacturing, assembling, maintaining, and repairing mechanical components.

Tuition & Fees: The estimated tuition for domestic students for the first two semesters of the program starting in Fall 2023 is $3,909.00. However, no information about additional costs or fees for materials, student services, and ancillaries is provided.

There is no explicit mention of a key information content from the text related to specific career options after completing the program.

Program Learning Outcomes: The graduate of this program will be able to comply with legislation, standards, regulations, and guidelines; contribute to quality control and assurance procedures; comply with current health and safety legislation and organizational practices; support sustainability best practices; use current and emerging technologies; troubleshoot mechanical problems using mathematics and mechanics fundamentals; interpret and prepare mechanical drawings; perform routine technical measurements; and assist in manufacturing, assembling, maintaining, and repairing mechanical components.

Tuition & Fees: The estimated tuition for domestic students for the first two semesters of the program starting in Fall 2023 is $3,909.00. However, no information about additional costs or fees for materials, student services, and ancillaries is provided.

There is no explicit mention of a key information content from the text related to specific career options after completing the program.

Program start dates: Two semesters starting in Fall 2023. (Note: This is a fast-track program where a full two semesters of work is completed in the May to August period.)
Fees: Fee information is given for programs starting in Fall 2023, but fees are subject to change for programs starting in Fall 2024 and at later dates. (Note: This fee does not include books, which are to be purchased by the student separately.)
CSA safety requirements: Students are responsible for purchasing CSA standard safety shoes for their protection when working in the laboratories. CSA safety glasses are provided, but students who wish to use prescription safety glasses will be responsible for purchasing those separately.
Financial Assistance: This program is approved for OSAP funding, provided the applicant meets OSAP eligibility criteria.
Admission Requirements: Applicants must currently be attending (or out of school for one semester) a university in Canada in a Mechanical and/or Industrial Engineering undergraduate program. They must have completed university Calculus I and Engineering Strategies and Practices (or Praxis) courses or their equivalent. For applicants who are 18 years and younger, proof of an Ontario Secondary School Diploma is required in addition to post-secondary transcripts.
Course exemptions: College or university credits may qualify students for course exemptions. More information can be found on the Transfer Guide.
Application process: Domestic students should apply through Ontario Colleges.
Contact Information: School of Mechanical Engineering Technologies - Phone: 416-415-5000, ext. 4365 / Email: engineeringtech@georgebrown.ca / Office hours: 8 a.m. – 4 p.m., room D305
Additional resources: George Brown College Contact Centre - Phone: 416-415-2000 (TTY 1-877-515-5559) or long distance 1-800-265-2002. / Visit the campus for an information session.
Related programs: Mechanical Engineering Technology – Design (T121)
